{\rtf1 hello and welcome to the grammar section}
{\rtf1 of the technical editing course and what}
{\rtf1 we're going to do today is we are going}
{\rtf1 to look at parts of speech to just kind}
{\rtf1 of outline the grammar section for you}
{\rtf1 it's going to be three videos the first}
{\rtf1 video will be introduction to grammar}
{\rtf1 and parts of speech video 2 will look at}
{\rtf1 sentence structure verbs and modifiers}
{\rtf1 more specifically and then video 3 will}
{\rtf1 look at nine common grammatical errors}
{\rtf1 so that's sort of the three major}
{\rtf1 sections of the grammar section of this}
{\rtf1 course so why is grammar so important}
{\rtf1 for editors besides obviously editors}
{\rtf1 need to know grammar the grammar of}
{\rtf1 English to be able to edit incorrect}
{\rtf1 errors in writing but secondarily so}
{\rtf1 primarily as editors we must be really}
{\rtf1 really good with the English language so}
{\rtf1 we can identify errors but secondarily}
{\rtf1 we got to be really really good at}
{\rtf1 curated building and curating}
{\rtf1 relationships with writers right so part}
{\rtf1 of our job as editors is interfacing}
{\rtf1 with writers and as we change their}
{\rtf1 writing which they inherently have some}
{\rtf1 stake or they inherently have some some}
{\rtf1 value that they've placed on that}
{\rtf1 writing when you're changing that kind}
{\rtf1 of things it can be difficult for}
{\rtf1 writers to take and so what what grammar}
{\rtf1 allows us to do is it gives editors}
{\rtf1 specific language right so we can we can}
{\rtf1 appeal to a dangling modifier or we can}
{\rtf1 say well this we need a stronger verb}
{\rtf1 phrase here or this sentence lacks or or}
{\rtf1 has some errors in subject verb}
{\rtf1 agreement so it gives us a language to}
{\rtf1 talk about sentences which is really}
{\rtf1 important as we're talking with writers}
{\rtf1 secondly it allows editors to rely on}
{\rtf1 objective evidence and not subjective}
{\rtf1 evidence or feel right so it allows us}
{\rtf1 to then go and we're changing this}
{\rtf1 sentence because it's grammatically}
{\rtf1 incorrect not because I didn't like the}
{\rtf1 word you used here or not because I}
{\rtf1 didn't like the order of the words you}
{\rtf1 used here we're actually using objective}
{\rtf1 evidence}
{\rtf1 for the particular error and then}
{\rtf1 thirdly it provides editors with}
{\rtf1 Authority which sort of follows the}
{\rtf1 previous two points of it gives us a}
{\rtf1 language to talk about sentences and it}
{\rtf1 makes it more concrete and so as we}
{\rtf1 enter into learning about grammar there}
{\rtf1 may be quite a bit of terminology that}
{\rtf1 you're familiar with there may be a bit}
{\rtf1 of terminology that you're not familiar}
{\rtf1 with I just encourage you to hang in}
{\rtf1 there as we go through parts of speech}
{\rtf1 so we'll start with parts of speech so}
{\rtf1 if we think about the traditional ways}
{\rtf1 in which we define parts of speech}
{\rtf1 they're typically defined semantically}
{\rtf1 and by semantically I mean by meaning so}
{\rtf1 if we look at a noun which is a part of}
{\rtf1 speech we we typically have learned in}
{\rtf1 grade school a noun is a person place or}
{\rtf1 thing that's a semantic definition or a}
{\rtf1 verb is an action word it's a word that}
{\rtf1 describes some kind of action and those}
{\rtf1 are good places to start but I would}
{\rtf1 argue that they aren't the best way or}
{\rtf1 the or they shouldn't be the only way}
{\rtf1 that we're identifying parts of speech}
{\rtf1 so if we take a word like running}
{\rtf1 without any context it's kind of hard to}
{\rtf1 know whether or not that's a verb it}
{\rtf1 kind of seems like a verb because it's}
{\rtf1 describing an action but if we look at}
{\rtf1 running in context we can take a look at}
{\rtf1 these two example sentences running}
{\rtf1 makes you healthy or I like to go}
{\rtf1 running right and in each case running}
{\rtf1 the same word is a different part of}
{\rtf1 speech right in the first case running}
{\rtf1 is a noun or functioning at least as a}
{\rtf1 noun and in the second case running I}
{\rtf1 like to go running as functioning as its}
{\rtf1 traditional sort of}
{\rtf1 describing an action as a verb so my}
{\rtf1 argument here is while traditional}
{\rtf1 semantics definitions are helpful}
{\rtf1 there's other ways that are even more}
{\rtf1 helpful for helping us identify parts of}
{\rtf1 speech and let's talk about each of}
{\rtf1 those ways so instead of using a}
{\rtf1 semantic identifier for identifying}
{\rtf1 parts of speech I would argue that we}
{\rtf1 should look at syntactic or structural}
{\rtf1 components of words to define parts of}
{\rtf1 speech and so to move past just}
{\rtf1 semantics or semantic categorization we}
{\rtf1 can look at parts of speech using simple}
{\rtf1 syntax and morphology and by syntax we}
{\rtf1 just mean}
{\rtf1 sentence structure the structure of a}
{\rtf1 sentence and by morphology we mean the}
{\rtf1 structure of individual words}
{\rtf1 so morphemes are the smallest semantic}
{\rtf1 unit in a language so if you take a word}
{\rtf1 and you chop it up a word like refund}
{\rtf1 has two morphemes REE and fund and so I}
{\rtf1 would argue that and we're going to take}
{\rtf1 a look at some examples of identifying}
{\rtf1 parts of speech using both syntax}
{\rtf1 sentence structure and morphology or}
{\rtf1 morphemes which is structure within a}
{\rtf1 word so let's walk through a series of}
{\rtf1 structural tests to identify parts of}
{\rtf1 speech so the first part of speech will}
{\rtf1 identify as nouns and nouns have three}
{\rtf1 major rules the first rule is nouns can}
{\rtf1 be pluralized and they can take a}
{\rtf1 possessive suffix so if we take an au}
{\rtf1 n-- like teacher well we can PluralEyes}
{\rtf1 teacher so we can say teacher that's the}
{\rtf1 singular or we can say two teachers we}
{\rtf1 can add an S to it and that's the plural}
{\rtf1 we can also give it a possessive suffix}
{\rtf1 teachers so teacher apostrophe s and}
{\rtf1 that is the possessive form of the word}
{\rtf1 teacher so the first rule is you can you}
{\rtf1 can PluralEyes it that's a pretty easy}
{\rtf1 one to understand the second rule is}
{\rtf1 they can be formed from verbs and}
{\rtf1 adjectives using inflectional suffixes}
{\rtf1 so things little little tales that you}
{\rtf1 can end that}
{\rtf1 you can add to an end of a word our}
{\rtf1 examples of inflectional suffixes}
{\rtf1 suffixes so three really common examples}
{\rtf1 are M ent tion and H ood so if we take a}
{\rtf1 verb like animate so I animated the}
{\rtf1 video and we add the inflectional suffix}
{\rtf1 T IO n we have now a verb I'm sorry a}
{\rtf1 noun form of the verb animate so}
{\rtf1 animation is a noun that's created out}
{\rtf1 of that verb anime so that's another}
{\rtf1 test or or rule and number three nouns}
{\rtf1 can be preceded by a determiner and}
{\rtf1 determiners are just often are like}
{\rtf1 articles v and a and so if we take the}
{\rtf1 example of teacher we can add a}
{\rtf1 determiner or an article before it the}
{\rtf1 teacher we take a noun like expectation}
{\rtf1 we can add an expectation or a noun like}
{\rtf1 hardship and we can say the hardship so}
{\rtf1 these are three structural tests or rule}
{\rtf1 and rules might actually not be the most}
{\rtf1 helpful word to describe these}
{\rtf1 structural tests is probably a better}
{\rtf1 way just because not all nouns will be}
{\rtf1 able to pass all three tests some might}
{\rtf1 pass one test some might test too and}
{\rtf1 some might pass the reason so we're just}
{\rtf1 using these structural tests to help us}
{\rtf1 determine whether or not something is a}
{\rtf1 noun or any other part of speech okay so}
{\rtf1 now that we've learned the three}
{\rtf1 structural tests for identifying nouns}

{\rtf1 on to}
{\rtf1 sighing verbs identifying verbs verbs}
{\rtf1 also have three rules or three}
{\rtf1 structural tests so one they can be made}
{\rtf1 past tense so that's a really easy one}
{\rtf1 so she walks that's the present tense}
{\rtf1 she walked that's the past tense that's}
{\rtf1 an easy way to test whether or not we've}
{\rtf1 got a verb number two they can follow}
{\rtf1 auxiliaries or and or modal's so}
{\rtf1 auxiliaries or modal verbs so has been}
{\rtf1 in this example a verb can follow those}
{\rtf1 auxiliaries and auxiliary or modal she}
{\rtf1 has been and then walking follows those}
{\rtf1 two and so that is a syntactic or}
{\rtf1 syntactic test for verb and then number}
{\rtf1 three can be negated with not or under}
{\rtf1 so you can make it a negative so she did}
{\rtf1 not walk versus she walked or the latch}
{\rtf1 was left unhooked versus the latch was}
{\rtf1 left hooked right so you can we know}
{\rtf1 that walk in hook and cooked our verbs}
{\rtf1 because we can add a negation to those}

{\rtf1 so adjectives adjectives just have one}
{\rtf1 rule these are the easiest I think to}
{\rtf1 identify they can take the comparative}
{\rtf1 form or the superlative form so tall}
{\rtf1 taller tallest}

{\rtf1 willing more willing most willing right}
{\rtf1 so some words don't take the ER EF t}
{\rtf1 suffixes they they get a word added to}
{\rtf1 them like more or most but those still}
{\rtf1 can take the comparative and superlative}
{\rtf1 forms finally identifying adverbs}
{\rtf1 adverbs}
{\rtf1 two rules the most the the easiest}
{\rtf1 structural test is can I take an ly}
{\rtf1 adverbs often end in ly so a word like}
{\rtf1 quickly is often it can be identified as}
{\rtf1 an adverb and then secondly they can't}
{\rtf1 appear between a determiner and a noun}
{\rtf1 so if we take a determiner like the word}
{\rtf1 Villa and a noun like Fox we can't put}
{\rtf1 an adverb between those two the quickly}
{\rtf1 Fox doesn't sound right and doesn't make}
{\rtf1 any sense we could say the quick Fox an}
